Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Piezoelectric Actuation for Tooth Extraction and Dental Procedures
Award.AbstractNarration:
Tooth extraction procedures have gone relatively unchanged for decades involving only minimal innovation focused around instrument refinement. Little progress has been made in the changing of the extraction process. Traditional tooth extractions require separation of the tooth from the surrounding gums by cutting of the tissue. This is followed by the extraction that uses the neighboring teeth as a fulcrum to wedge the tooth from the socket. As a result, partial extraction (leaving the roots) and adjacent tooth breakage can occur, thereby causing local trauma and extra healing time. In this proposal, a mechanism employing vibratory motion to loosen the tooth from the gum tissue without cutting and subsequently vibrate the tooth from the socket has been proposed. The vibration mechanism will be integrated into existing dental instruments. The result is a less traumatic removal of the tooth and a reduced time for healing. With an annual market of 8 billion dollars in the dental field associated with tooth extractions, the introduction of these devices is timely and viable. Further, the use of this technology in the veterinary field where the market potential may be twice that associated with human tooth extractions makes for a less burdensome undertaking and can provide a validated method and process prior to FDA regulatory compliance.

The proposal seeks to achieve tooth extraction via oscillatory motion. The loosening of the tooth is accomplished by employing a piezoelectric actuator which displays displacement proportional to the electric current applied. The displacement characteristics of these actuators can be altered by varying the frequency and magnitude of the current through the device. Due to their small geometry, they can be incorporated into existing instruments currently utilized in the dental field. In the new extraction process, the tooth is separated from the restraining tissues using a non-cutting vibrating blade secured to a piezoelectric handle (periotome). The tooth is secured using the traditional instrument (forceps) equipped with the piezoelectric device and vibrated loose from the socket rather than pulled in the traditional manner. The new extraction process employing vibratory motion reduces local trauma, reduces healing time, and minimizes the likelihood of adjacent tooth damage since surrounding teeth are often used as lever arms to aid in the extraction process. Incorporation of the piezo-actuation into the traditional dental instruments will permit a reduced learning curve and improve the likelihood of acceptance by clinicians as minimal deviations from conventional practice is involved.During the I-Corps curriculum, the team will access the market opportunity, refine the minimum viable product and outline commercialization plans for the device platform capable of transforming an existing 6 billion dollar annual market.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project validated the commercial and clinical viability opportunity of utilizing vibratory motion technology for the purpose of more efficient and less traumatic tooth extraction.  This process was initiated by conducting over 100 interviews which included dentists ranging from early career individuals to those who have been in practice for and extensive period of time. Also included were specialists such as oral surgeons, cosmetic dentists, periodontists, and pediatric dentists. Interviewing this large range of clinicians would provide an overall market need for this technology. One of the most significant outcomes with the interview process was that the extraction process requires three distinct steps; resection of the restraining soft tissue, elevation of the tooth, and removal with forceps. Based on the response from the interviewees, tooth elevation is the most crucial step in the extraction of the tooth and where the incidence of tooth breakage is most likely to occur. Approximately 50% of those interviewed confirmed they would use dental technology that would minimize the incidence tooth breakage. 

 

Intellectual Merit:

 

When practitioners were presented with the theory of low frequency vibration to separate the soft tissues from the tooth followed by tooth oscillation under similar conditions all agreed that such a concept would be of significant interest.  Separation of the tooth from the restraining tissues is currently performed using a periotome; a thin sharp blade used to cut the soft tissue restraints. The elevation of the tooth is performed through sequential application of cantilever forces until the tooth becomes loose within the socket. In both these processes the use of low-frequency vibration can be applied. The separation of the soft tissue from the tooth at low frequencies will not cause stiffening in the soft tissues while in the elevation phase the low-frequency oscillations are comparable to manual manipulations currently used to loosen the tooth within the socket.

When confronted with the concept involving the newly designed periotome and elevator device clinicians agreed that if properly developed within geometrical, regulatory and, economic constraints such a process would be of value to their practice. When meeting with manufacturers, one remarked that such a device and concept would radically change the field. It was relayed to the team during this conversation that the dental field is not being presented with a significant change in decades and that such a device(s) may fulfill a new technological and clinical need.  Preliminary in-vitro experiments employing prototype electronics and devices have resulted in tooth translations in excess of 200% following vibration as compared to pre-vibration movement.

Broader Impacts:

Regarding dental training, use of this technology could be employed during traditional training at dental schools. In addition, it may be possible that dental assistants may perform the separation and elevation phase of the extraction with the dentist only required to verify sufficient tooth loosening prior to physically extracting the tooth with the forceps.  The successful realization of these two devices through low-frequency vibrations for tooth extraction will significantly improve the process and outcomes for tooth removal. With a target market of approximately 5.8 million annual extractions, the development of these devices is timely. Use of these devices may appease the fears associated with dentists. While the correlation between oral and cardiovascular health is not definitive, there is growing evidence for its existence.


Last Modified: 08/26/2016
Modified by: Antonio Valdevit
